text: Find the co-factors of the elements of the matrix: $\begin{pmatrix} -1 & 2 \\ -3 & 4 \end{pmatrix}$
Find the matrix of co-factors for the matrix: $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 4 & -1 \end{pmatrix}$
answer:
Step 1: Find the co-factor for each element.
$A_{11}=(-1)^{1+1}(-1)=-1$.
$A_{12}=(-1)^{1+2}(4)=-4$.
$A_{21}=(-1)^{2+1}(3)=-3$.
$A_{22}=(-1)^{2+2}(1)=1$.
Step 2: Arrange the co-factors into a matrix.
The matrix of co-factors is $\begin{pmatrix} A_{11} & A_{12} \\ A_{21} & A_{22} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -1 & -4 \\ -3 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$.

text: Find the adjoint of the matrix: $\begin{pmatrix} 2 & -3 \\ 3 & 5 \end{pmatrix}$
answer:
Step 1: Let $A = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & -3 \\ 3 & 5 \end{pmatrix}$. First, find the matrix of co-factors.
$A_{11}=5$, $A_{12}=-3$, $A_{21}=-(-3)=3$, $A_{22}=2$.
Step 2: The matrix of co-factors is $\begin{pmatrix} 5 & -3 \\ 3 & 2 \end{pmatrix}$.
Step 3: The adjoint of A is the transpose of the co-factor matrix.
adj(A) = $\begin{pmatrix} 5 & 3 \\ -3 & 2 \end{pmatrix}$.

text: Find the inverse of the matrix $\begin{pmatrix} -1 & 5 \\ -3 & 2 \end{pmatrix}$ by the adjoint method.
answer:
Step 1: Let $A = \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 5 \\ -3 & 2 \end{pmatrix}$. Find the determinant: $|A| = (-1)(2) - (5)(-3) = -2 + 15 = 13$.
Step 2: Find the matrix of co-factors: $\begin{pmatrix} 2 & 3 \\ -5 & -1 \end{pmatrix}$.
Step 3: Find the adjoint: adj(A) = $\begin{pmatrix} 2 & -5 \\ 3 & -1 \end{pmatrix}$.
Step 4: Find the inverse: $A^{-1} = \frac{1}{|A|}\text{adj}(A) = \frac{1}{13} \begin{pmatrix} 2 & -5 \\ 3 & -1 \end{pmatrix}$.

text: Find the inverse of the matrix $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 2 & -1 \end{pmatrix}$ by elementary row transformations.
answer:
Step 1: Start with $AA^{-1}=I$: $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 2 & -1 \end{pmatrix} A^{-1} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$.
Step 2: Apply $R_2 \rightarrow R_2 - 2R_1$: $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 0 & -5 \end{pmatrix} A^{-1} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ -2 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$.
Step 3: Apply $R_2 \rightarrow -\frac{1}{5}R_2$: $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} A^{-1} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 2/5 & -1/5 \end{pmatrix}$.
Step 4: Apply $R_1 \rightarrow R_1 - 2R_2$: $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} A^{-1} = \begin{pmatrix} 1/5 & 2/5 \\ 2/5 & -1/5 \end{pmatrix}$.
Step 5: Therefore, $A^{-1} = \frac{1}{5} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 2 & -1 \end{pmatrix}$.
